content: The "Panama Canal Amendments Act of 1994" amends Section 1101 of the Panama Canal Act of 1979 regarding the establishment, purposes, offices, and residence of the commission. The Panama Canal Commission is established as a government corporation for managing the Panama Canal and its operations under the Panama Canal Treaty of 1977. The President's authority over the Commission is exercised through the Secretary of Defense, with the principal office located in Panama. The Panama Canal Commission may establish branch offices in other necessary places for its business. It is considered an inhabitant of the District of Columbia and the eastern judicial district of Louisiana. Section 1102 of the Panama Canal Act of 1979 is amended accordingly. The supervisory board is established by the Panama Canal Commission. The Panama Canal Commission establishes a supervisory board with nine members, including the Secretary of Defense or a designated officer. At least five members must be U.S. nationals, and the rest are from Panama. Three U.S. members must have no other government affiliations and vote as directed by the Secretary of Defense. Amendments aim to enhance the Commission's prestige. The United States and Panama may each invite an international advisor to the Panama Canal Commission's Board to provide an independent perspective, who is not a national of either country, does not represent any user or interest group of the Panama Canal, and has no financial conflicts with the Board or Commission. Designated international advisors may be compensated by the Commission in the same manner as Board members, but they have no voting rights. The Commission has general powers. The Commission has the power to adopt a corporate seal, bylaws, and to sue and be sued in its corporate name, with limitations on its amenability to suit. The Commission has the power to enter into contracts, determine obligations and expenditures, and acquire, hold, and dispose of property and rights. The Commission has the authority to acquire, hold, and dispose of property and rights, including franchises, concessions, and licenses necessary for its purposes. Additionally, it has priority in debt payment from bankrupt estates. The Commission has specific powers to acquire, hold, and dispose of property and rights, including franchises, concessions, and licenses necessary for its purposes. The Commission has the authority to manage, operate, and maintain the Panama Canal, as well as construct and operate various facilities and business activities necessary for its operation. The Commission has the authority to manage, operate, and maintain the Panama Canal, as well as provide services, equipment, supplies, and materials to vessels, US government agencies, employees, and other eligible entities. They can also use the United States mails for their operations. The Panama Canal Commission has the authority to manage the canal, provide services, and use the United States mails. Amendments are made to sections of the Panama Canal Act of 1979 regarding budget review by Congress. Amendments are made to the Panama Canal Act of 1979, allowing the Commission to hire independent auditors for financial audits. The audited financial statements must ensure the Commission's ability to meet financial liabilities by December 31, 1999. The curr_chunk is about the "prescription of measurement rules and rates of tolls" in the context of the Panama Canal Act of 1979 amendments. The Commission has the authority to set rules for vessel measurement and toll rates for the Panama Canal, with changes requiring public notice in the Federal Register at least 30 days prior to taking effect. The Panama Canal Act of 1979 is amended to change certain sections related to appropriations and funds. Section 9101(3) of title 31, United States Code, is also modified. Section 9101(3) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include the Panama Canal Commission.
